text:
Former President Donald Trump and 18 
others have been indicted in Georgia

over alleged efforts to overturn 
the results of the 2020 election.

And the search continues for human 
remains on the island of Maui.

Good morning. I'm Windsor Johnston, with 
NPR News, and here are today's top stories:

Prosecutors in Georgia have indicted 
former President Donald Trump. NPR's

Carrie Johnson reports Trump and 18 others 
are facing a barrage of criminal charges for

their alleged efforts to overturn the 
state's results of the 2020 election:

"Beyond the the overarching charge of a 
racketeering, there are a number of other,

more specific charges, including solicitation 
of violation of oath by public officer,

false statements and writings, and 
impersonating a public officer, forgery,

some document-related charges 
and false statements charges."
That's NPR's Carrie Johnson reporting.

Access to west Maui is still being 
restricted as authorities continue

to search for human remains in Lahaina after 
deadly wildfires. Officials in Hawaii say at

least 99 people have died in the fires. 
NPR's Lauren Sommer reports residents on

the island are feeling isolated, lacking 
power and cell service in some areas:

"We're hearing from some residents in Lahaina that 
they're eager to get back to central Maui — there,

they can get better wifi, supplies and even 
search for loved ones. The more direct route

there is being restricted by authorities; they 
say that road needs to be left open for utility

trucks and supply chains. If residents 
leave, they have to take a much longer,

hourlong road that's very windy and dangerous. 
Today, residents in Lahaina got a text message

that they should gather to get special 
placards to put in their cars to speed

their return to Lahaina. Many waited hours 
to get their placard. The site was quickly

overwhelmed, and authorities shut it down 
and said they are abandoning that system.
"Lauren Sommer, NPR News, Lahaina."

Lawyers in Alabama are awaiting a ruling from 
federal judges over whether the state's new

congressional map satisfies a Supreme Court 
ruling early this year. Stephan Bisaha,

of Gulf States Newsroom, reports the state was 
ordered to create two majority black districts,

but the panel of judges raised questions 
over the state's new submission:

"Alabama's justification for ignoring the Supreme 
Court? A new map and new rules means the court's

order no longer matters. Alabama recently changed 
its standards for drawing congressional maps,

so the state's attorneys say its newest map 
should be judged against those new standards,

not whether it made two districts where a 
minority candidate had a chance at winning.

The three federal judges running the 
hearing did not seem impressed — the

same judges who initially found Alabama 
violated the Voting Rights Act. One judge

said it seemed like Alabama deliberately 
ignored the court's instructions. If the

judges reject the new map, they could appoint 
their own officials to draw brand new one.
"For NPR News, I'm Stephan Bisaha, in Birmingham."
This is NPR News.
